Define horizontal asymptotes and determine if a function has them graphically or algebraically

definition.title: Limits at Infinity
definition.p: Let f be a function defined on some interval (a,\infty). Then \lim_{x\to\infty} f(x) = L means that the values of f(x) can be made arbitrarily close to L by requiring x to be sufficiently large.
If g is defined on some interval (-\infty,a), then \lim_{x\to-\infty} g(x) = L means that the values of g(x) can be made arbitrarily close to L by requiring x to be sufficiently large negative.

subsubsection.p:
We read the limits above (for f) as
the limit of f(x), as x approaches \infty, is L
the limit of f(x) as x increases without bound, is L
with the obvious changes for g

definition.title: Horizontal Asymptote
definition.statement:
The line y=L is called a horizontal asymptote of the curve y=f(x) if either
\lim_{x\to\infty} f(x) = L\qquad \text{or}\qquad \lim_{x\to -\infty} f(x) = L

example.statement: Write the horizontal asymptotes of the function f(x) = \dfrac{x^2-1}{x^2 + 1}
Write the horizontal asymptotes of the function f(x) = \ds \lim_{x\to \infty} \dfrac{3x-2}{2x+1}.
Does the function f(x) = \dfrac{1-x^2}{x^3-x+1} have any horizontal asymptotes? If it does, give their equation. If it doesn't, explain why.
The function f(x) = \dfrac{x-9}{\sqrt{4x^2 + 3}} has two horizontal asymptotes: L = \dfrac{1}{2} and L = - \dfrac{1}{2}. Use limit notation to describe the horizontal asymptotes.

question.statement: Think about \ds \lim_{x\to\infty} \dfrac{1}{x} and \ds \lim_{x\to -\infty} \dfrac{1}{x}. What do you expect these limits to be? Why? What about \ds \lim_{x\to \pm \infty} x^r, for some r \gt 0?

assemblage.title: Theorem
assemblage.p: If r\gt 0 is a rational number, then \ds \lim_{x\to \infty} \dfrac{1}{x^r} = 0. If r \gt 0 is a rational number such that x^r is defined for all x, then \ds \lim_{x\to -\infty} \dfrac{1}{x^r} = 0

example.statement: Find the limits as x\to \pm \infty. Use this information, together with intercepts, to give a rough sketch of the graph y = x^4 - x^6.
